study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-arthritic potential of lupeol compared to indomethacin in a collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rat model.
results_summary: Lupeol significantly reduced inflammatory markers, cytokines, paw volume, and histological changes while enhancing apoptosis. It also reverted hematological and biochemical alterations associated with arthritis, suggesting anti-inflammatory and apoptotic effects.
population_specificity: Collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rats
effective_dosage: 10 mg/kg body weight (lupeol), 3 mg/kg body weight (indomethacin)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of intra-articular hyaluronic acid (IA-HA) and oral NSAIDs on urinary CTX-II levels in knee osteoarthritis patients to understand their differing modes of action.
results_summary: IA-HA increased urinary CTX-II levels, while NSAIDs reduced them, suggesting distinct mechanisms of symptom improvement in knee osteoarthritis. The between-group difference in CTX-II changes was statistically significant.
population_specificity: 200 knee osteoarthritis patients from 20 hospitals.
effective_dosage: IA-HA (2,700 kDa, 5 injections at 1-week intervals) or NSAID (loxoprofen sodium, 180 mg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to extract and characterize Type-II Collagen from blue shark cartilage and assess its biochemical properties for potential biomedical applications.
results_summary: The study successfully isolated Type-II Collagen from blue shark cartilage, confirming its structural integrity, high purity, and typical collagen properties, including fibrous microstructure, amino acid composition, and thermal stability.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on extracted collagen).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immunomodulatory and therapeutic effects of oral undenatured type II collagen on osteoarthritis, focusing on pain reduction, functional improvement, and joint protection.
results_summary: The study found that oral undenatured type II collagen significantly reduced pain, improved musculoskeletal function, and may offer protection against joint damage from mechanical stress in both affected and healthy joints. The mechanism involves systemic tolerance, inhibition of proinflammatory processes, and enhancement of anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Patients with osteoarthritis (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate type II collagen (CII)-containing scaffolds combined with hyaluronic acid (HyA) to enhance cartilage repair by improving MSC chondrogenesis and cartilage-like matrix formation.
results_summary: The CII-containing scaffolds, especially when combined with HyA, showed enhanced deposition and distribution of sulphated glycosaminoglycans (sGAG) by day 28, indicating improved chondrogenic benefits compared to traditional type I collagen scaffolds. The scaffolds exhibited high porosity (99%) and mechanical properties similar to optimized collagen-based scaffolds.
population_specificity: Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) in vitro (cartilage tissue engineering context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of resveratrol monotherapy on serum levels of type II collagen (Coll 2-1) and aggrecan in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Resveratrol administration led to a nonsignificant decrease in Coll 2-1 serum levels but a significant increase in aggrecan. It also significantly improved pain scores (VAS and KOOS) and functional status after 30 days, with sustained benefits over three months.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 500 mg/day in a single oral dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether modifying mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) with palmitated protein G (PPG) and type II collagen antibody could enhance targeted delivery and engraftment for cartilage repair.
results_summary: The study found that PPG-modified MSCs successfully conjugated with type II collagen antibody without affecting cell proliferation or differentiation. The antibody-conjugated MSCs showed improved attachment to osteochondral surfaces, suggesting potential for targeted therapy in cartilage defects.
population_specificity: Bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) in vitro and in osteochondral defect explants.
study_duration: Attachment assessed within 48 hours; other durations not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a specific assay for measuring type II collagen degradation (T2CM) and assess its potential as a noninvasive biomarker for osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The T2CM assay was technically robust and specific for type II collagen fragments cleaved by MMP-1 and -13. Elevated T2CM levels were found in end-stage OA patients, and salmon calcitonin treatment reduced T2CM levels compared to placebo.
population_specificity: OA patients (end-stage and moderate) and those receiving salmon calcitonin treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory and therapeutic effects of tomatidine (Td) on TNFα-induced arthritic fibroblast-like synoviocytes (FLSs) and collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) in rats.
results_summary: Td significantly inhibited TNFα-induced proliferation and migration of arthritic FLSs, ameliorated synovial inflammation and joint destruction in CIA rats, and suppressed pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, TNFα) and downregulated MMP-9 and RANKL expression. The effects were linked to decreased activation of MAPKs (ERK, JNK) and NF-κB.
population_specificity: Rats with collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) and TNFα-induced arthritic fibroblast-like synoviocytes (FLSs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vorinostat could protect against IL-1α-induced reduction of type II collagen in osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Vorinostat prevented IL-1α-induced reduction of type II collagen at gene and protein levels, reduced mitochondrial ROS production, and inhibited MMP-13 and ELF3 expression, which are involved in collagen degradation.
population_specificity: T/C-28a2 cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of Q-1, a coumarin derivative, in regulating rheumatoid arthritis (RA) via the NF-κB signaling pathway using a bovine type II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rat model.
results_summary: Q-1 significantly reduced arthritis indices, ankle joint swelling, inflammatory cytokine levels (IL-1β, IL-6, MCP-1), and NF-κB pathway proteins (IκB, P-IκB, P65, P-P65) in CIA rats, demonstrating anti-inflammatory and RA-inhibiting effects.
population_specificity: Bovine type II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rat model.
effective_dosage: High dose (30 mg·kg⁻¹) and low dose (15 mg·kg⁻¹), administered intragastrically.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Telmisartan could mitigate TNF-α-induced degradation of type II collagen in chondrocytes and its potential role in treating osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Telmisartan reduced TNF-α-induced oxidative stress and proinflammatory mediators, restored type II collagen levels, and acted mechanistically by restoring SOX-9 expression, suggesting its potential as an OA treatment.
population_specificity: Human C28/I2 chondrocytes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether marine-derived Type-II Collagen (SCII) could accelerate fracture healing by regulating muscle paracrine factors and activating specific signaling pathways.
results_summary: SCII significantly reduced TNF-α and increased aggrecan levels by day 5, accelerated chondrocyte proliferation and mineralization by day 10, and elevated key growth factors (IGF-1, irisin) and bone formation markers (Wnt10b, β-catenin, Runx2) through the Ihh/PThrp and Wnt/β-catenin pathways.
population_specificity: Mice with induced tibial fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CII-specific ACAID B cells could induce immune tolerance in mice, potentially offering therapeutic benefits for CII-mediated autoimmune diseases.
results_summary: The study found that adoptive transfer of CII-specific ACAID B cells significantly suppressed immune responses in mice challenged with CII, demonstrating immune tolerance across three different mouse strains (C57BL/6, BALB/c, and DBA/1).
population_specificity: Mice (C57BL/6, BALB/c, and DBA/1 strains)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the preventive and therapeutic effects of undenatured type II collagen (UC II) on osteoarthritis in aging db/db mice and patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: UC II significantly improved motor functions, reduced inflammatory and oxidative stress markers, and enhanced physical activity in both mice and human subjects. Pain, stiffness, and physical function scores decreased, while mobility metrics improved.
population_specificity: Aging db/db mice and 55 T2DM patients diagnosed with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effects of undenatured type II collagen (UC-II) on joint inflammation and pain in a monoiodoacetate (MIA)-induced osteoarthritis (OA) model and investigate potential mechanisms.
results_summary: UC-II reduced MIA-induced joint damage (53.3%), lowered inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α, COMP, CRP), inhibited cartilage degradation markers (PGE2, COX-2, NF-κB, MMP-3), and increased protective factors (COL-1, OPG).
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats with MIA-induced osteoarthritis.
study_duration: Seven days of UC-II treatment before MIA induction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-arthritic effects of SC-E3, a polyherbal formula, in a mouse model of type-II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA).
results_summary: SC-E3 demonstrated anti-arthritic effects by reducing paw swelling, bone erosion, inflammatory cell infiltration, and pro-inflammatory cytokines in CIA mice. It also inhibited osteoclastogenesis in bone marrow-derived macrophages.
population_specificity: Male DBA/1J mice with type-II collagen-induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of dextrose prolotherapy versus hyaluronic acid injections on urinary C-terminal telopeptide of type II collagen levels and pain scores in knee osteoarthritis patients.
results_summary: Dextrose prolotherapy significantly reduced urinary C-terminal telopeptide of type II collagen levels and pain scores compared to hyaluronic acid, but neither treatment affected serum cartilage oligomeric proteinase levels.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (47 participants: 21 hyaluronic acid, 26 dextrose prolotherapy).
effective_dosage: Dextrose prolotherapy group received 3 injections (weeks 1, 5, and 9); hyaluronic acid group received 5 injections (weeks 1-5).
study_duration: Follow-up measurements were taken 3 weeks after the last injection (total duration varied by group: ~12 weeks for dextrose prolotherapy, ~8 weeks for hyaluronic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential biomarkers, including type II collagen cleavage neoepitope (C2C), to detect early-stage musculoskeletal changes in brucellosis patients.
results_summary: The study found significantly elevated serum levels of C2C in early-stage male brucellosis patients compared to controls, suggesting its potential as a biomarker for osteoarticular changes in brucellosis.
population_specificity: 41 male early-stage brucellosis patients (within 6 months of diagnosis) and 44 matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anti-rheumatoid arthritis (RA) effect and mechanism of ethyl acetate extract of Rhamnella gilgitica (RGEA) on collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) in rats.
results_summary: RGEA treatment restored body weight, reduced arthritis index and paw swelling, decreased inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-17, TNF-α, INF-γ), increased anti-inflammatory cytokines (IL-4, IL-10), promoted synovial cell apoptosis, and modulated the JAK-STAT pathway.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with collagen-induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate synthetic triple helical peptides (THPs) from Type-II Collagen for detecting autoantibodies in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients to aid in early diagnosis and treatment selection.
results_summary: The study found that synthetic THPs effectively detected autoantibodies in RA patients, with increased antibody levels against specific CII epitopes compared to controls, highlighting the importance of triple-helical conformation for epitope recognition.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis and control individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of GPR17 in TNF-α-induced reduction of type II collagen and explore pranlukast's potential to protect type II collagen degradation in osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that pranlukast, a GPR17 antagonist, prevented TNF-α-induced reduction of type II collagen and suppressed MMP-3 and MMP-13 expression, which degrade collagen. It also inhibited oxidative stress and pro-inflammatory pathways, suggesting GPR17 as a potential therapeutic target for osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: ATDC5 cells (a chondrogenic cell line) exposed to TNF-α.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a sensitive detection method for uCTX-II, a biomarker for osteoarthritis, using antibody-conjugated gold nanoparticles on an interdigitated electrode.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a detection strategy with a sensitivity of 10 pM and a linear response to increasing uCTX-II concentrations, confirming specific detection without interference from controls.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus was on methodological development).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of the GPR40 agonist GW9508 on protecting Type-II Collagen and aggrecan from degradation in AGEs-treated chondrocytes.
results_summary: GW9508 protected Type-II Collagen and aggrecan by reducing the expression of degrading enzymes (MMP-3, MMP-13, ADAMTS-4, ADAMTS-5) and pro-inflammatory cytokines, while suppressing NF-κB activation in AGEs-induced chondrocytes. These effects were mediated by GPR40, as co-treatment with antagonist GW1100 abolished the benefits.
population_specificity: Human SW1353 chondrocytes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the regenerative potential of demineralized bone matrix with a collagen membrane (GTR) versus eggshell components (including its type X collagen membrane) in periodontal defects.
results_summary: Both treatments showed intensive new bone formation, complete defect healing, and resolved inflammation with no significant differences between them, though the test group (eggshell components) had more connective tissue.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with induced periodontal defects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of decitabine (DAC) on a murine model of rheumatoid arthritis induced by Type-II Collagen.
results_summary: DAC administration significantly improved clinical conditions in mice, reducing Th1 and Th17 pro-inflammatory cytokines and lowering anti-Type-II Collagen autoantibodies. The study demonstrated beneficial immunological modifications in treated mice.
population_specificity: Murine model (mice) with rheumatoid arthritis induced by Type-II Collagen.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between urinary C-Telopeptide fragments of type II collagen (uCTX-II) and knee joint moments, pain, and physical function in individuals with medial knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found no relationship between uCTX-II levels and knee moments but reported significant correlations between uCTX-II levels and pain, physical function, and 40m walk test performance. uCTX-II levels explained 9% of pain scores, 27% of physical function scores, and 7% of walk test performance.
population_specificity: 25 subjects radiographically diagnosed with medial knee OA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether blocking the SDF-1/CXCR4 signaling pathway with three antagonists (TN14003, T140, AMD3100) could delay articular cartilage degeneration by reducing MMP expression and preserving Type-II Collagen and aggrecan.
results_summary: The study found that all three antagonists reduced SDF-1 levels and MMP expression while increasing Type-II Collagen and aggrecan mRNA levels, with TN14003 showing the strongest effect in delaying cartilage degeneration.
population_specificity: Male Duncan-Hartley guinea pigs (6 months old)
effective_dosage: 180 μg/ml daily for each antagonist (TN14003, T140, AMD3100)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between Type-II collagen cleavage products (CTX-II) and structural joint damage in knee osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found that higher levels of CTX-II correlated with increased MRI-detected joint damage (e.g., cartilage degradation, bone marrow lesions, and synovitis), suggesting CTX-II as a biomarker for OA severity. However, the study did not assess the direct therapeutic effects of Type-II collagen supplementation.
population_specificity: Adults with mild or advanced knee osteoarthritis and non-OA controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the pharmacological mechanisms of Guizhi-Shaoyao-Zhimu (GSZD) in treating Type II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) in rats and its effects on synovial fibroblasts.
results_summary: GSZD reduced toe swelling, arthritis scores, and inflammatory cytokines in CIA rats, improved joint pathology, and exhibited anti-proliferative, pro-apoptotic, and anti-invasive effects on synovial fibroblasts. It also modulated apoptosis-related gene expressions.
population_specificity: Type II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rat model and TNF-α stimulated MH7A cells (human synovial fibroblasts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the persistence, biodistribution, and genomic integration risk of the DNA vaccine pcDNA-CCOL2A1 encoding chicken type II collagen (CCII) for rheumatoid arthritis treatment.
results_summary: The study found that CCOL2A1 mRNA and CCII protein were rapidly cleared, with no genomic integration, and expression was transient in specific tissues, supporting its safety profile for RA treatment.
population_specificity: Normal vaccinated rodents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanistic effects of glycyrrhizin (GL) and/or platelet-rich plasma (PRP) treatment on collagen-induced arthritis in rats.
results_summary: The study found that combined treatment with GL and PRP significantly improved inflammation and autophagy biomarkers, reduced HMGB-1 and beclin-1 levels, downregulated LC3 mRNA expression, and restored antioxidant status by inhibiting MPO activity and inducing catalase and Nrf2-DNA binding activities.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats with collagen-induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lunasin could mitigate cartilage degradation by suppressing MMPs and preserving type II collagen in the context of osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Lunasin suppressed MMP-3 and MMP-13 increases, prevented TIMP-1 and TIMP-2 reductions, and attenuated type II collagen loss, suggesting potential chondro-protective effects. It also inhibited the JAK2/STAT1/IRF-1 pathway.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal model based on abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saxagliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor, could protect Type-II collagen from degradation by reducing the expression of cartilage-degrading enzymes in human chondrocytes.
results_summary: Saxagliptin significantly decreased the expression of MMP-1, MMP-3, MMP-13, ADAMTS-4, and ADAMTS-5, preventing Type-II collagen and aggrecan degradation. It also reduced oxidative stress and acted through the p38/IκBα/NF-κB pathway.
population_specificity: Primary human chondrocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of undenatured type II collagen (UC-II) and robenacoxib on improving mobility in dogs with osteoarthritis.
results_summary: UC-II and robenacoxib showed similar efficacy in reducing LOAD and MOBILITY scores, with UC-II achieving a 32.7% improvement (p = 0.013). Both treatments significantly improved mobility in dogs with osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: Client-owned dogs affected by osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate immunomodulatory peptides from Type-II Collagen (CII) in chick sternal cartilage using a novel CIEH-MS system and evaluate their potential applications.
results_summary: The CIEH-MS system effectively isolated immunomodulatory peptides with high lymphocyte proliferation activity (85.54%) and binding ability to HLA-DRB1 molecules (133.2 ng/ml), demonstrating potential for functional foods and medical applications.
population_specificity: Chick sternal cartilage (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of integrin α2β1 in T-2 toxin-induced chondrocyte damage and its impact on type II collagen production.
results_summary: The study found that T-2 toxin reduced type II collagen production and increased MMP-13 levels in chondrocytes, but integrin α2β1 inhibitor blocked matrix degradation.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats and C28/I2 chondrocytes
effective_dosage: 100 ng/g BW/day (in vivo); 0, 6, 12, and 24 ng/mL (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify biomarkers of efficacy for intra-articular hyaluronic acid (HYMOVIS®) in knee osteoarthritis and assess its potential disease-modifying effects.
results_summary: The study found increased type II collagen turnover (Coll2-1 and PIIANP levels), improved cartilage volume in lateral knee compartments, reduced synovitis, and enhanced KOOS scores, suggesting positive structural and symptomatic effects.
population_specificity: 46 patients with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Two treatment cycles of intra-articular HYMOVIS® (8 mg/mL, 3 mL per injection), each cycle involving two injections 1 week apart, repeated at 6-month intervals.
study_duration: 1 year (with follow-up at baseline and 1 year).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the diagnostic value of 68Ga-citrate and 18F-FDG PET/CT in detecting type II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) in rats.
results_summary: 68Ga-citrate PET/CT was significantly superior to 18F-FDG PET/CT for imaging CIA, showing earlier and more sensitive detection of inflammatory activity in affected joints, with this advantage persisting into later stages of inflammation.
population_specificity: Rats with type II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA).
study_duration: Evaluated at 23 days (early) and 40 days (late) post-induction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of paeonol in inhibiting factors related to osteoarthritis, including the degradation of type II collagen.
results_summary: Paeonol demonstrated the ability to inhibit multiple OA-related factors, including IL-6, TNF-α, NOX2, PTGS2, NUCB2/nesfatin-1, ICAM-1, VCAM-1, MMP-3/13, and degradation of type II collagen, while also suppressing NF-κB activation. Cell viability tests confirmed its safety.
population_specificity: Chondrogenic cell line ATDC5 cells cultured with IL-1β.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether activation of TGR5 using INT-777 could protect against TNF-α-induced degradation of type II collagen and other ECM components in chondrocytes.
results_summary: Activation of TGR5 with INT-777 reduced TNF-α-induced degradation of type II collagen and aggrecan by inhibiting MMP-3, MMP-13, ADAMTS-4, and ADAMTS-5 expression, and suppressed the IKK/IκBα/NF-κB signaling pathway. Knockdown of TGR5 abolished these protective effects, confirming its involvement.
population_specificity: Human primary chondrocytes and human chondrosarcoma SW1353 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of salicin on AGE-induced degradation of type II collagen and aggrecan in human chondrocytes, as well as its potential to reduce oxidative stress and inflammation.
results_summary: Salicin demonstrated a beneficial role in rescuing degradation of type II collagen and aggrecan, reducing oxidative stress, attenuating proinflammatory cytokines, and inhibiting the NF-κB pathway in AGE-stimulated chondrocytes.
population_specificity: SW1353 human chondrocytes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and molecular mechanism of IL-10-modified BMSCs in treating CIA rats induced by Type-II Collagen.
results_summary: IL-10-modified BMSCs significantly improved body weight, reduced ankle swelling, enhanced forced swimming time, promoted cartilage repair, and suppressed synovial proliferation compared to untreated or BMSCs-only groups. Serum levels of inflammatory cytokines (IL-17, IL-1ß, TNF-alpha) were lower, and SIRT1 protein levels in peripheral blood mononuclear cells and spleen were modulated.
population_specificity: CIA (collagen-induced arthritis) rat model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Saururus chinensis leaf water extract (SHW) on type II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) in mice.
results_summary: SHW (500 mg/kg) reduced serum levels of IL-6, TNF-alpha, and collagen IgG, decreased hind limb swelling, and reduced monocyte infiltration in CIA mice. The results suggest SHW may mitigate arthritis symptoms by lowering inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: Type II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) mouse models.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg and 500 mg/kg SHW, orally administered.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether type II collagen extract could enhance immune responses in rats with deteriorated immunity caused by methotrexate.
results_summary: Type II collagen extract significantly increased body weight, total blood leukocyte numbers, total lymphocyte numbers in the spleen, and the ratio of CD4+ and CD8+ T-cells in both blood and spleen compared to the control group. The results suggest that type II collagen extract can improve immune function in rats with methotrexate-induced immune deterioration.
population_specificity: SD rats with methotrexate-induced deteriorated immunity.
effective_dosage: 250 mg/kg and 500 mg/kg, administered once daily via gastric gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-rheumatoid arthritis effects of Anoectochilus roxburghii polysaccharides (ARP) using a rat model of type II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA).
results_summary: ARP significantly reduced arthritis symptoms, decreased inflammatory cell infiltration, and inhibited synovial tissue destruction in CIA rats. It also suppressed the NF-κB pathway, down-regulated IL-1β and IL-6 mRNA expressions, and exhibited antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Rats with type II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether estradiol (E2) protects against intervertebral disc degeneration (IVDD) by modulating Type-II Collagen expression in a rat model.
results_summary: E2 reversed IVDD by decreasing caspase-3, MMP-3, and MMP-13 expression while increasing Type-II Collagen expression, effects blocked by estrogen receptor inhibition.
population_specificity: Three-month-old female Sprague Dawley rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether type II collagen stimulates nucleus pulposus-like differentiation of adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs) and the role of FoxA2 in this process.
results_summary: Type II collagen promoted NP-like differentiation of ADSCs by increasing FoxA2 expression, and FoxA2 overexpression enhanced NP-specific gene expression and extracellular matrix synthesis. FoxA2-overexpressing ADSCs combined with type II collagen hydrogels improved regeneration of degenerated NP in vivo.
population_specificity: Adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs) and in vivo models of intervertebral disc degeneration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of glucosamine methyl ester on cartilage degeneration, including Type-II Collagen levels, in an osteoarthritis rat model.
results_summary: Glucosamine methyl ester significantly reduced cartilage degeneration, increased Type-II Collagen levels, and inhibited inflammatory markers like interleukin-1β and matrix metalloproteinases. The highest dose (10 mg/kg) showed the most pronounced effects, with Type-II Collagen levels increasing ~3.6-fold compared to untreated rats.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats with induced osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether gemigliptin could inhibit IL-1β-induced degradation of type II collagen in human chondrocytes and its potential as a therapeutic strategy for osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Gemigliptin inhibited the expression of MMP-1, MMP-3, and MMP-13 at gene and protein levels, suppressed NF-κB signaling pathway activation, and reduced phosphorylation of IKK/IκBα and p38, suggesting chondroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Human chondrocytes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sodium butyrate influences IL-1β-induced degradation of type II collagen in human chondrocytes in the articular cartilage matrix.
results_summary: Sodium butyrate significantly reduced IL-1β-induced up-regulation of MMP-1, MMP-3, and MMP-13, suppressed TIMP-1 and TIMP-2 expression, and attenuated type II collagen degradation by inhibiting NF-κB activation.
population_specificity: Human chondrocytes from patients with osteoarthritis (OA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory and anti-arthritic effects of crocin on type II collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) in Wistar rats.
results_summary: Crocin mitigated RA symptoms in CIA rats, including reducing arthritis scores, paw swelling, joint inflammation, and pro-inflammatory cytokine expression. The highest dose (40 mg/kg) restored histological scores and MMP levels to near-normal levels.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with type II collagen-induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a Type-II Collagen/chondroitin sulfate composite hydrogel (CCSA) as a delivery system for adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs) to regenerate degenerated nucleus pulposus (NP) tissue.
results_summary: The CCSA system promoted NP-specific gene expression, restored disc height, water content, and extracellular matrix synthesis, and improved the structure of degenerated NP in a rat model. The system demonstrated biocompatibility and regenerative potential with minimal invasiveness.
population_specificity: Rat coccygeal vertebrae degeneration model (animal study).
effective_dosage: 0.02% genipin cross-linked CCSA (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the motility of dental pulp stem cells (DPSCs) and DPSC-derived chondrogenic cells in type I and type II collagen hydrogels for potential disc regeneration.
results_summary: DPSCs showed high viability in both non-crosslinked and crosslinked collagen hydrogels. Migration speed of DPSC-derived chondrogenic cells was higher in type I collagen hydrogel than in type II, and crosslinking type I collagen reduced their migration speed.
population_specificity: In vitro study using dental pulp stem cells (DPSCs) and DPSC-derived chondrogenic cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate and characterize squid-derived type II collagen (SCII), evaluate its immunogenicity compared to bovine type II collagen (BCII), and assess its anti-inflammatory and osteoarthritis-relieving effects.
results_summary: SCII showed no immunogenicity, reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines, prevented chondrocyte hypertrophy, impeded macrophage chemotaxis, and alleviated inflammation in OA rats.
population_specificity: OA rat model (in vivo) and pro-inflammatory macrophages (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether SAMC could protect chondrocytes from IL-1β-induced damage and explore its potential mechanisms, including effects on Type-II collagen degradation.
results_summary: SAMC improved chondrocyte viability, increased Type-II collagen levels, reduced degradation products, and modulated the MMPs/TIMP-1 ratio. It also suppressed TNF-α and NF-κB signaling, suggesting a protective role in osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: In vitro chondrocyte model (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) combined with adipose-derived stem/stromal cells (ADSCs) could reduce type II collagen (COL2-1) degradation and modulate inflammation in a rat model of osteoarthritis.
results_summary: PBMT and ADSCs upregulated COL2-1 mRNA and protein expression, reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines and MMPs, and prevented joint degeneration in the osteoarthritis model. The combination showed chondroprotective effects compared to the OA group.
population_specificity: Female Fischer 344 rats with induced osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 10 × 10^6 ADSCs injected intra-articularly; PBMT parameters: 808 nm wavelength, 50 mW power, 42 J energy, 71.2 J/cm² energy density, 0.028 cm² spot size.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of combining type II collagen hydrogel, fibrin sealant, and adipose-derived stem cells (ASCs) for repairing focal articular cartilage defects in rabbit knees.
results_summary: The combination of type II collagen hydrogel, fibrin sealant, and ASCs promoted chondrogenic differentiation in vitro and improved cartilage repair in vivo, evidenced by increased proteoglycan production, collagen type II expression, and better tissue organization compared to treatments without ASCs.
population_specificity: Rabbit knees with chondral defects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the structural requirements for recombinant chicken type II collagen (rCCII) assembly and its effectiveness in treating rheumatoid arthritis compared to native CCII (nCCII).
results_summary: The study found that recombinant CCII (rCCII) could assemble without C- and N-propeptides or telopeptides, and rCCII pCα1(II) was as effective as nCCII in inducing collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) in a rat model. CTEs (tolerogenic epitopes) formed stable homotrimers and were secreted, while larger procollagens were retained intracellularly.
population_specificity: Collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of PPAR-δ agonist, hBM-MSCs, and HA gel could overcome synovial inflammation and enhance the formation of type II collagen-producing chondrocytes in osteoarthritis (OA) patients.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of PPAR-δ agonist, hBM-MSCs, and HA gel significantly enhanced the formation of type II collagen-producing chondrocytes within OA synovial fluid, overcoming synovial inflammation, whereas individual components alone were ineffective.
population_specificity: Human OA synovial fluid samples from 3 different donors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether undenatured native chicken type II collagen (UC-II) could prevent excessive articular cartilage deterioration in a rat model of osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: UC-II treatment preserved weight-bearing capacity, maintained cancellous bone integrity, and limited osteophyte formation and cartilage deterioration in rats with induced OA.
population_specificity: Male rats with surgically induced osteoarthritis via partial medial meniscectomy tear (PMMT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether IL-1β inhibits type II collagen expression and whether curcumin can counteract this effect by inhibiting NF-κB signaling.
results_summary: Curcumin inhibited IL-1β-induced NF-κB activation, leading to downregulation of MMP-13 and upregulation of type II collagen expression, and increased chondrocyte proliferation.
population_specificity: Rat articular chondrocyte cell cultures

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combinatorial effect of betulinic acid and fluvastatin on atherogenesis during arthritis induced by bovine type-II collagen.
results_summary: The combination therapy significantly reduced arthritic index, inflammatory markers, and oxidative stress while enhancing anti-inflammatory cytokine expression, suggesting a potential reduction in rheumatoid arthritis and cardiovascular disease risk.
population_specificity: Arthritic patients (induced by bovine type-II collagen in the study).
effective_dosage: Bovine type-II collagen dissolved in 0.01M acetic acid at 4mg/mL, emulsified in incomplete Freund's adjuvant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of KLF2 in inhibiting cartilage matrix destruction, specifically its effects on type-II collagen degradation in chondrocytes.
results_summary: KLF2 overexpression inhibited IL-1β-induced MMP-13 expression and reduced type-II collagen degradation, while KLF2 knockdown exacerbated these effects, suggesting KLF2 as a potential therapeutic target for osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: Human chondrocytes, including primary chondrocytes and OA chondrocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-dose halofuginone (HF) could inhibit type I collagen synthesis without affecting type II collagen in chondrocytes, potentially improving cartilage regeneration.
results_summary: The study found that HF inhibited type I collagen synthesis by suppressing the TGF-β signaling pathway (via Smad2/3 phosphorylation inhibition and Smad7 promotion) while preserving type II collagen, suggesting a potential method to convert fibrocartilage into hyaline cartilage during regeneration.
population_specificity: Chondrocytes (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Nebivolol could protect against IL-1β-induced degradation of type II collagen and MMP-13 expression in cartilage matrix.
results_summary: Nebivolol reversed IL-1β-induced degradation of type II collagen in a dose-dependent manner and reduced MMP-13 expression and activity by inhibiting NF-κB and IRF-1 pathways.
population_specificity: In vitro cell culture model (specific human or animal cell type not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if type-II collagen scaffolds, with or without chondroitin sulfate, could promote chondrogenic differentiation of human bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells to potentially prevent osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Type-II collagen scaffolds stimulated abundant collagen type-II production, and the addition of chondroitin sulfate significantly upregulated type II collagen gene expression compared to type-I and pure type-II scaffolds. The study concluded that type-II collagen and chondroitin sulfate can promote a chondrogenic phenotype without growth factors.
population_specificity: Human bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory effect and mechanism of action of Zaocys type II collagen on collagen-induced arthritis in mice.
results_summary: Zaocys type II collagen reduced arthritis scores and histological inflammation dose-dependently, increased regulatory-T cells, decreased T-helper 17 cells, and modulated cytokine levels (higher TGF-β, lower IL-17A).
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with collagen-induced arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects and mechanisms of Periplocoside A (PSA) on collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) in mice, focusing on its role in regulating Th17/Treg cell balance.
results_summary: PSA administration significantly reduced arthritis severity, joint damage, and anti-collagen II antibody levels while modulating Th17/Treg cell balance and suppressing pro-inflammatory cytokines. The study demonstrated PSA's efficacy in alleviating CIA symptoms through immune regulation.
population_specificity: DBA/1 mice with collagen-induced arthritis (CIA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of oral native type II collagen combined with acetaminophen for improving symptoms and biological markers of cartilage degradation in knee osteoarthritis patients.
results_summary: The study found that combining type II collagen with acetaminophen significantly improved joint pain, function, and quality of life compared to acetaminophen alone, though no significant improvements were observed in biochemical markers of cartilage degradation.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with knee osteoarthritis (n=39).
effective_dosage: 10 mg/day of native type II collagen.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of reducing ultraprocessed food intake as part of a comprehensive nutritional intervention to improve metabolic and cardiovascular health in ASCVD patients.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in ultraprocessed food consumption, alongside improvements in glycemic control, lipid profiles, and metabolic syndrome remission. Participants also showed enhanced adherence to healthier dietary patterns like the Mediterranean diet.
population_specificity: Patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular diseases (ASCVD) and metabolic comorbidities (prediabetes or metabolic syndrome).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a breastfeeding and healthy complementary feeding intervention reduced ultraprocessed food (UPF) consumption in children aged 4-7 years.
results_summary: The intervention reduced the risk of high UPF consumption by 35% compared to the control group, with mean UPF intake at 38% (intervention) vs. 42.7% (control). Breastfeeding duration did not affect UPF consumption.
population_specificity: Teenage mothers and their infants from South Brazil.
study_duration: Intervention began in the maternity ward and continued at home after delivery; follow-up at 4-7 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether higher consumption of ultraprocessed foods is associated with an increased risk of chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that higher consumption of ultraprocessed foods was independently associated with a 24% increased risk of incident CKD, with a linear relationship observed. Substituting one serving of ultraprocessed foods with minimally processed foods reduced CKD risk by 6%.
population_specificity: 14,679 middle-aged adults without CKD at baseline from the Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities (ARIC) study.
effective_dosage: Servings per day (quartiles of consumption, exact amounts not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile evidence that ultraprocessed food, particularly added sugar, meets public health criteria for regulation (abuse, toxicity, ubiquity, and externalities) and to propose intervention strategies.
results_summary: The study found that ultraprocessed food, especially added sugar, is linked to non-communicable diseases (NCDs) and meets the criteria for public health regulation. Some countries have implemented sugar taxation as an intervention, but broader societal measures are needed due to food industry interference.
population_specificity: Global population, with a focus on Western diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between PEP-1-SIRT2 and the expression of MMP-1, MMP-13, and type II collagen in rabbit articular chondrocytes, focusing on dedifferentiation mechanisms.
results_summary: PEP-1-SIRT2 increased MMP-1 and MMP-13 expression, leading to decreased type II collagen levels, which was reversed by MMP inhibition or ERK pathway suppression.
population_specificity: Rabbit articular chondrocytes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the binding effects and inhibitory activity of dietary flavone glycosides, including uridine-related compounds, on UGT enzymes, particularly UGT2B7.
results_summary: The study found that flavone O-glycosides like rutin had high binding affinities and inhibitory effects on UGT2B7, while flavone C-glycosides and phenolic acid metabolites showed no significant impact. In vitro experiments indicated no significant effect on UGT gene expression after 24-hour exposure.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: 10 μM (for rutin, nicotifiorin, isovitexin, and other tested compounds)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of a low-carbohydrate ketogenic diet as a treatment for binge eating and ultraprocessed food addiction by examining its proposed mechanisms.
results_summary: The study suggests that ultraprocessed, refined, or high-glycemic-index carbohydrates may trigger neurochemical responses similar to addiction, leading to overeating and hunger exacerbation. Reducing or abstaining from these foods could be an effective treatment approach, supported by recent case series.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on individuals with binge eating or ultraprocessed food addiction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether uridine supplementation could effectively treat symptoms associated with biallelic hypomorphic CAD variants, primarily focusing on hematological and developmental outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that uridine supplementation improved the patient's condition, including hematological abnormalities and mild developmental delay, despite functional studies not showing complete abrogation of CAD protein function. The response to uridine suggests its therapeutic potential for CAD-related disorders.
population_specificity: A single patient with biallelic CAD variants presenting with macrocytic anemia, elevated hemoglobin-A2 levels, anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, target cells, and mild developmental delay.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of uridine-cytidine kinase 2 (Uck2) in the mutagenic activity of β-d-N4-hydroxycytidine (NHC) and its implications for ribonucleoside metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that inactivating Uck2 reduced NHC-induced mutagenesis, while over-expression of Uck2 enhanced it, suggesting that differences in ribonucleoside metabolism contribute to variable mutagenicity of NHC in cancer cell lines and primary tissues.
population_specificity: Mouse myeloid cell line and cancer cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between ultraprocessed food (UPF) consumption and pulmonary function test results in adults with asthma.
results_summary: The study found that increased UPF consumption was associated with decreased % FVC expected and % FEV1/FVC values, indicating worsened respiratory function, though no significant relationship was found between UPF consumption and % FEV1 expected value.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 to 65 diagnosed with asthma and receiving medical treatment (n=339).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential drug-drug interactions (DDIs) of vericiguat, focusing on its metabolism via UGT1A9 and UGT1A1, and evaluate the impact of genetic polymorphisms on its pharmacokinetics.
results_summary: The study predicted no clinically relevant DDI between vericiguat and the UGT1A1 inhibitor atazanavir, with minor AUC and peak plasma concentration increases. It also suggested a modest AUC increase (up to 1.7-fold) in subpopulations with reduced UGT1A1 and UGT1A9 activity due to genetic polymorphisms.
population_specificity: Not specified (preclinical and modeling study)
interactions: Potential interaction with UGT1A1 inhibitors (e.g., atazanavir) and UGT1A9 inhibitors (e.g., mefenamic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the rationale for abstaining from uridine triacetate in cases of 5-FU overdose, questioning its clinical and cost-effectiveness.
results_summary: The study reported two cases of 5-FU overdose where uridine triacetate was not used; one patient developed no toxicity, and the other recovered fully with best supportive care. The authors argue that evidence supporting uridine triacetate's effectiveness is inadequate and advocate for further comparative studies.
population_specificity: Two elderly female patients (71 and 74 years old) with normal DPYD genotypes who experienced 5-FU overdose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether uridine levels are altered in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) tissues and if uridine could be a potential therapeutic target for HCC.
results_summary: The study found higher expression of uridine synthesis genes (CAD and DHODH) in HCC tissues compared to non-tumor tissues, with lower uridine content in tumor tissues. Uridine inhibited HCC cell proliferation, invasion, and migration by activating the ferroptosis pathway.
population_specificity: Patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and corresponding adjacent non-tumor tissues.
effective_dosage: High concentrations (specific amounts not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether uridine serves as a metabolic fuel for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) cells under glucose-deprived conditions and its potential role in tumor progression.
results_summary: The study found that uridine, metabolized via UPP1, supports PDA cell survival and proliferation in glucose-restricted conditions by fueling central carbon metabolism and maintaining redox balance. High UPP1 expression correlated with poor patient survival, and UPP1 deletion reduced tumor growth in mouse models.
population_specificity: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) cell lines and immunocompetent mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of uridine (Urd) in improving constipation-related parameters and associated molecular mechanisms in C3-deficient mice.
results_summary: Uridine improved stool parameters, gastrointestinal transit, intestinal epithelial barrier function, mucin secretion, water retention, and enteric nervous system regulation in C3-deficient mice.
population_specificity: FVB/N-C3em1Hlee/Korl knockout (C3 KO) mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether epilepsy patients with variant UGT2B7 -161C>T or UGT1A4*3 c.142 T>G alleles had different lamotrigine exposure compared to wild-type peers.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in dose-adjusted lamotrigine troughs between variant allele carriers and wild-type controls, both in monotherapy and valproate co-treatment groups. Results were consistent across frequentist and Bayesian analyses.
population_specificity: Epilepsy patients on lamotrigine monotherapy or lamotrigine + valproate co-treatment, generally healthy and free of interacting drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether uridine exerts a protective effect against neurotoxin-induced Parkinson's disease (PD) symptoms in rats, specifically through activation of the mitochondrial ATP-dependent potassium (mitoK-ATP) channel.
results_summary: Uridine restored neurotoxin-induced behavioral and biochemical changes, including improved motor function, reduced oxidative stress, and preserved mitochondrial integrity. The protective effects were blocked by a mitoK-ATP channel inhibitor, indicating the channel's involvement in uridine's mechanism.
population_specificity: Rats with 6-OHDA-induced Parkinson's disease-like symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate hydrogen abstraction reactions in uridine and guanosine through quantum chemical calculations to determine reaction rate constants.
results_summary: The study found that the hydrogen abstraction reaction at the C4' position in uridine's ribofuranose part had a rate constant of 1.62×10^10 L mol^-1s^-1, showing similarity to guanosine despite differing nucleobases.
population_specificity: Not applicable (computational study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate uridine's suitability as an actinometer for validating germicidal photon flux in UVC systems, particularly for water disinfection.
results_summary: Uridine's absorption spectrum closely matches microbial inactivation sensitivity in the 240-290 nm range, making it an ideal actinometer for UVC systems. The protocol is effective for both traditional LP mercury lamps and newer UV-LED sources.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on microbial inactivation and photon flux validation).

study_goal: The researchers sought to characterize accidental and intentional capecitabine exposures and evaluate the use of uridine triacetate as an antidote.
results_summary: Uridine triacetate was effective in preventing new or progressive toxicity when administered within 96 hours of capecitabine exposure, with no reported morbidity or mortality. Most cases were managed at home, and only mild latent toxicity was observed in a few cases.
population_specificity: Patients with accidental or intentional capecitabine exposures, including acute-on-chronic and acute exposures in capecitabine-naïve individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR) regulates UGCG (uridine diphosphate glucose ceramide glucosyltransferase) and its role in ceramide metabolism, keratinocyte differentiation, and epidermal barrier formation.
results_summary: The study found that AHR activation increased UGCG RNA levels and ceramide metabolites, enhancing keratinocyte differentiation and barrier function. Tapinarof, an AHR ligand, also upregulated UGCG and related genes, while Ahr-null mice showed reduced Ugcg RNA and ceramide levels.
population_specificity: Normal human epidermal keratinocytes and Ahr-null mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate uridine as a non-toxic, photochemical actinometer for monitoring UV-C reactor designs in the food industry.
results_summary: Uridine was found to be as accurate as the standard iodide/iodate actinometry but less precise, requiring more measurements at higher concentrations. A temperature correction was also developed for use between 10°C and 30°C.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the clinical features and therapeutic effects of uridine in children with developmental epileptic encephalopathy 50 (DEE50) caused by CAD gene variants.
results_summary: Uridine supplementation led to immediate cessation of seizures, significant improvement in anemia and brain atrophy, and normalization of visual evoked potentials in children with DEE50. Most patients achieved long-term seizure freedom, either with uridine monotherapy or combined with anti-seizure medications.
population_specificity: 6 pediatric patients (3 boys, 3 girls) aged 3.2-5.8 years with uridine-responsive DEE50 caused by CAD gene variants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the immunogenicity and expression stability of the uridine analogue 5-ethynyluridine (EU) compared to other uridine analogues (Ψ and mΨ) for potential use in RNA-based vaccines and therapeutics.
results_summary: The study found that EU does not induce immune activation in human macrophages, lacks inflammatory gene expression, and allows prolonged protein expression, though at lower levels than unmodified or other modified uridines. EU showed similar stability and low immunogenicity to Ψ and mΨ, suggesting its potential for RNA-based applications.
population_specificity: Human macrophages (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether uridine could mitigate mitochondrial dysfunction and skeletal muscle damage in dystrophin-deficient mdx mice, a model for Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
results_summary: Uridine reduced fibrosis and improved potassium ion transport and reactive oxygen species production but had no significant effect on muscle strength, inflammation, mitochondrial ultrastructure, or calcium retention capacity. It partially normalized mitophagy-related gene expression but did not resolve OXPHOS dysfunction.
population_specificity: Dystrophin-deficient mdx mice (model for Duchenne muscular dystrophy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of uridine triacetate (UTA) in treating delayed central nervous system toxicity caused by fluoropyrimidine chemotherapy, even beyond the recommended 96-hour window.
results_summary: The study found that UTA rapidly improved clinical status and resolved encephalopathy in a patient with delayed 5-FU toxicity, suggesting its potential efficacy beyond the standard treatment window. Literature review and clinical trial reports supported the use of UTA for life-threatening delayed toxicity on a case-by-case basis.
population_specificity: A 64-year-old male with stage IIIA rectal cancer experiencing delayed 5-FU-induced CNS toxicity, later identified as heterozygous for DPD deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of uridine on acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and insulin resistance in a mouse model.
results_summary: Uridine treatment significantly attenuated lung histopathological alterations, reduced proinflammatory cytokines, decreased total cells and neutrophils in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, and improved insulin sensitivity by down-regulating NF-κB signaling and reducing inflammation and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: LPS-induced ARDS mice model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of valproic acid, a uridine diphosphate-glucuronosyltransferase inhibitor, on the pharmacokinetics of vixotrigine and its metabolites.
results_summary: Valproic acid increased vixotrigine systemic exposure by approximately 70%, decreased M13 metabolite exposure by 50%, and increased M14 and M16 metabolite exposures by approximately 100% and 70%, respectively.
population_specificity: 30 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: Vixotrigine 150 mg single dose; valproic acid 500 mg three times daily
interactions: Valproic acid significantly altered vixotrigine pharmacokinetics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate uridine's antidiabetic potential and its effects on mitochondrial homeostasis in the heart tissue of diabetic mice.
results_summary: Uridine normalized plasma glucose and triglyceride levels, improved glucose utilization, prevented mitochondrial and sarcomere abnormalities, and restored mitochondrial biogenesis and mitophagy-related gene expression. It also reduced oxidative phosphorylation dysfunction and lipid peroxidation but did not significantly affect calcium retention capacity or potassium transport.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with high-fat diet-streptozotocin-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether UGT1A6 expression was altered by valproic acid (VPA) and to elucidate the mechanism behind this change, focusing on AhR and Nrf2 pathways.
results_summary: VPA treatment increased UGT1A6 mRNA by 7.9-fold in Caco-2 cells, mediated through AhR and Nrf2 pathways but not ERK or JNK pathways. Other HDAC inhibitors similarly induced UGT1A6 mRNA, suggesting HDAC inhibition as the underlying mechanism.
population_specificity: Caco-2 cells (human colon adenocarcinoma cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of uridine administration on levels of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) and their inhibitors (TIMPs) in rats subjected to REM sleep deprivation.
results_summary: Uridine treatment significantly improved the impairment of MMP-3, MMP-9, and TIMP-3 levels and MMP-9 activity caused by REM sleep deprivation, but had no effect on TIMP-1, MMP-2, TIMP-2 levels, or MMP-2 activity.
population_specificity: Rats subjected to 96-hour REM sleep deprivation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify UGT1A isoforms involved in SN-38 glucuronidation and assess how genetic variants of these isoforms affect glucuronidation activity in vitro.
results_summary: The study found that UGT1A1 and UGT1A6-UGT1A10 exhibit SN-38 glucuronidation activity, with UGT1A1 being the most active. Variants of these isoforms showed reduced glucuronidation activity, suggesting a link between UGT1A variants and irinotecan-induced adverse effects.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of uridine in rescuing metabolic and proliferation deficits caused by OXPHOS dysfunction in primary mitochondrial diseases.
results_summary: Uridine supplementation, combined with pyruvate, fully rescued the altered metabolic profile and proliferation deficits in fibroblasts from PMD patients and increased survival in a zebrafish rotenone model.
population_specificity: Patients with diverse primary mitochondrial diseases (PMD) and a zebrafish model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to create new 5-substituted uridine derivatives as potential inhibitors of SARS-CoV-2 RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
results_summary: The study synthesized uridine derivatives with high yields but found no significant inhibitory effect against SARS-CoV-2 in antiviral activity testing.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or in vivo context not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to create new 5-substituted uridine derivatives as potential inhibitors of SARS-CoV-2 RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
results_summary: The study synthesized uridine derivatives with high yields, but testing revealed no significant inhibitory effect against SARS-CoV-2.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or in vivo testing not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether uridine has anti-aging effects, particularly on intestinal aging, using in vivo and in vitro models.
results_summary: Uridine significantly reduced aging markers (Sa-β-gal-positive cells), inflammation, and oxidative stress in intestinal cells and mice, demonstrating anti-aging effects.
population_specificity: In vitro intestinal cell models and in vivo mice models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-aging effects of uridine on senescent gastric epithelial cells and its impact on FGF signaling pathways.
results_summary: Uridine significantly reduced aging markers (p16, p21), decreased SA-β-gal-positive cells, lowered inflammation and oxidative stress, and partially restored FGF signaling sensitivity in senescent gastric epithelial cells.
population_specificity: Senescent gastric epithelial cells (in vitro model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of oral uridine monophosphate (UMP) in treating developmental and epileptic encephalopathy type 50 caused by CAD pathogenic variants.
results_summary: Treatment with oral UMP resulted in rapid and remarkable clinical improvement in developmental progress and seizure control in two siblings with CAD pathogenic variants. The study also reviewed and summarized previous literature on similar cases.
population_specificity: Two siblings with CAD pathogenic variants presenting with developmental regression and intractable epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the regenerative potential and long-term functional effects of Uridine treatment in a rat model of sciatic nerve injury.
results_summary: Uridine treatment improved functional recovery (SFI and nerve conduction velocity), enhanced nerve adherence, separability scores, and increased the number of myelinated axons compared to the control group. The results suggest short-term Uridine treatment provides morphological and electrophysiological benefits leading to long-term functional improvement.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with sciatic nerve injury
study_duration: 7 days of treatment, monitored for 12 weeks post-surgery

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if uridine, a pyrimidine nucleoside, could rejuvenate aged human stem cells and promote tissue regeneration in vivo.
results_summary: The study found that uridine rejuvenated aged human stem cells and promoted regeneration of various tissues in vivo, correlating with active pyrimidine metabolism linked to higher regenerative capacity.
population_specificity: Aged human stem cells and in vivo tissue regeneration models (axolotl limb blastema, antler stem cells, primate juvenile and aged tissues).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate uridine's potential role in alleviating CCl4-induced liver fibrosis in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Uridine effectively reduced collagen accumulation, improved liver cell activity, and alleviated CCl4-induced liver injury by down-regulating α-SMA, collagen type-I, and fibronectin expression.
population_specificity: CCl4-induced liver fibrosis models (in vitro and in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether uridine could alleviate senescence in chondrocytes and mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) and relieve osteoarthritis (OA) in in vitro and in vivo models.
results_summary: Uridine reduced senescence markers in chondrocytes and MSCs in vitro and alleviated OA symptoms in vivo, demonstrating potential for treating age-related OA.
population_specificity: In vitro models of chondrocytes and MSCs, and in vivo OA models (specific organism not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a concise and cost-effective synthesis method for Molnupiravir to improve global accessibility.
results_summary: The study reported a novel one-pot synthesis method for Molnupiravir, achieving 62% yield and >99% purity using inexpensive bulk chemicals. This approach reduces purification steps and enhances affordability.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on synthesis methodology, not human trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of uridine monophosphate (Ur) in a ferret model of inflammation-sensitized hypoxic-ischemic brain injury.
results_summary: Uridine monophosphate (Ur) worsened motor outcomes compared to controls and did not provide meaningful neuroprotection. HI animals treated with Ur took longer to complete motor assessments, and Ur failed to mitigate injury-related cortical and white matter damage.
population_specificity: Near-term postnatal day 17 ferrets with inflammation-sensitized hypoxic-ischemic brain injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of SHP-2 inhibition in osteoarthritis (OA) and its effect on uridine levels and cartilage metabolism.
results_summary: SHP-2 inhibition increased uridine levels by reducing uridine phosphorylase 1 expression, contributing to cartilage homeostasis. This mechanism helped maintain the anabolic-catabolic balance in OA.
population_specificity: Human OA cartilage samples and mouse models (DMM-induced OA and IL-1β-stimulated chondrocytes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical implications of the uridine diphosphate glucuronosyltransferase family 1 member A1*28/*28 genotype in patients receiving sacituzumab govitecan-hziy, particularly regarding neutropenia risk.
results_summary: The study found that uridine diphosphate glucuronosyltransferase family 1 member A1*28 homozygous expressors are at increased risk for severe neutropenia with sacituzumab govitecan-hziy, but this did not correlate with higher febrile neutropenia risk. No clear guidance exists for dose adjustments or prophylactic measures in these patients.
population_specificity: A 38-year-old pre-menopausal female of South Asian descent with metastatic triple-negative breast cancer.
effective_dosage: 10 mg/kg/dose on days 1 and 8 of a 21-day cycle (later dose-reduced).
study_duration: Until disease progression (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of oral uridine supplementation in a patient with SLC25A36 deficiency, focusing on improvements in thyroid function, growth, and developmental progress.
results_summary: Oral uridine supplementation improved thyroid function, alleviated obstipation, and enhanced growth and developmental progress in the patient. The study suggests uridine as a safe and effective treatment for SLC25A36 deficiency-related symptoms.
population_specificity: A 12-year-old patient with SLC25A36 deficiency presenting hypothyroidism, hyperinsulinism, hyperammonemia, chronical obstipation, short stature, and developmental delay.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Uridine diphosphate glucosyltransferases (UGTs), specifically TcUgt86Dg, in the detoxification of Artemisia vulgaris essential oil in Tribolium castaneum.
results_summary: The study found that A. vulgaris essential oil significantly induced TcUgt86Dg expression, and silencing this gene increased mortality, indicating its role in detoxification. Higher expression was observed in late adults and specific tissues like the head, antenna, fat body, and accessory gland.
population_specificity: Tribolium castaneum (red flour beetle) larvae and adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of uridine and guanosine in an asthma model, focusing on their molecular pathways.
results_summary: Uridine reduced lung inflammation in OVA-challenged mice, decreasing total cell counts in BALF, cytokines (IL-4, IL-6, IL-13), OVA-specific IgE, and mRNA levels of inflammatory markers. It also suppressed MAPK and NF-κB pathways in vivo and in vitro.
population_specificity: OVA-challenged mice (asthma model) and LPS/IFN-γ-induced THP-1 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether uridine + pyruvate supplementation could mitigate the off-target effects of mitotoxic antibiotics on immune cell function in patients with asymptomatic bacteriuria or positive sperm culture.
results_summary: The study found that uridine + pyruvate supplementation led to a 3.4-fold higher differential lymphocyte count and a 3.7-fold increase in the percentage of dividing T cells compared to the control group, suggesting enhanced immune cell activity during antibiotic treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with asymptomatic bacteriuria or positive sperm culture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between methylglyoxal and uridine diphosphate-induced carotid arterial contraction in rats and whether p38 MAPK was involved in these responses.
results_summary: Methylglyoxal enhanced uridine diphosphate-induced contraction in rat carotid arteries, likely through activation of p38 MAPK, protein kinase C, and increased oxidative stress. The augmentation was prevented by N-acetyl-L-cysteine.
population_specificity: Rats (isolated carotid arterial rings)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate uridine's effect on myocardial ischemic and reperfusion injury and establish a possible mechanism for its cardioprotective action.
results_summary: Uridine (30 mg/kg) prevented energy depletion, maintained antioxidant activity, reduced lipid hydroperoxides and diene conjugates, and decreased myocardial necrosis and heart rhythm disturbances. Its effects were limited by the mitoKATP channel blocker 5-hydroxydecanoate, suggesting uridine's cardioprotection may involve mitoKATP activation.
population_specificity: Rat models of acute myocardial ischemia and ischemia/reperfusion injury.
study_duration: 60-min ischemia or 30-min ischemia followed by 120-min reperfusion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-apoptotic and anti-oxidant effects of systemic uridine treatment in a rat model of sciatic nerve injury.
results_summary: Uridine at 500 mg/kg significantly reduced apoptosis and exhibited strong anti-oxidant effects, while 100 mg/kg showed modest anti-apoptotic and anti-oxidant benefits compared to controls.
population_specificity: Adult male rats with sciatic nerve injury
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg and 500 mg/kg, administered intraperitoneally once daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of UDP-glucose (UDP-G) and the P2Y14R receptor in eosinophil accumulation and airway hyperresponsiveness (AHR) during type 2 inflammation in asthma.
results_summary: The study found that UDP-G activates P2Y14R on eosinophils, promoting their migration into the lungs, and that inhibiting P2Y14R reduced eosinophil infiltration and AHR, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for asthma.
population_specificity: The study focused on eosinophils in the context of allergic asthma, but the specific human or animal population is not detailed in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anti-HBV and immunostimulatory effects of msiRNAs incorporating unpaired uridine bulges in the passenger strand.
results_summary: msiHBx significantly reduced HBsAg and HBV DNA levels while increasing antiviral cytokines (TNF-α, IFN-α, IFN-β) without proinflammatory activation, demonstrating dual RNAi and immunostimulatory activity.
population_specificity: HepG2 cells, HepG2.2.15 cells, and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how SARS-CoV-2 Nsp15, a uridine-specific endoribonuclease, recognizes uridine and to identify potential inhibitors like Tipiracil for therapeutic intervention against COVID-19.
results_summary: The study revealed the structural basis for uridine recognition by Nsp15 and identified Tipiracil as an inhibitor that binds to the uridine pocket, suggesting its potential as an anti-COVID-19 drug. The findings support the development of uracil-based drugs targeting Nsp15.
population_specificity: In vitro and structural studies (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of uridine supplementation on seizure control, developmental regression, and cerebellar atrophy in siblings with biallelic CAD variants.
results_summary: Uridine supplementation led to dramatic improvements in seizure control, development, and cessation of cerebellar atrophy in the younger sibling, while the older sibling showed only modest response. The treatment demonstrated efficacy in halting disease progression in one case.
population_specificity: Two siblings with intractable epilepsy, developmental regression, and progressive cerebellar atrophy due to biallelic CAD variants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical, hematologic, and biochemical effects of uridine triacetate in a patient with hereditary orotic aciduria (HOA) caused by a novel UMPS gene variant.
results_summary: The patient showed clinical, hematologic, and biochemical improvement after starting uridine triacetate, indicating its effectiveness in managing HOA symptoms. The study highlights uridine triacetate as a potential treatment for this rare condition.
population_specificity: A 17-year-old Emirati girl with hereditary orotic aciduria (HOA) and a novel UMPS gene variant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of uridine, in combination with choline and DHA, in addressing nutritional deficiencies and cognitive decline in individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) due to Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study found that a multinutrient intervention including uridine slowed brain atrophy and improved some cognitive measures in individuals with prodromal AD. Uridine was identified as a conditionally essential nutrient in this population, as dietary intake alone could not correct its shortage.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) due to Alzheimer's disease (prodromal AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of uridine supplementation in treating CAD deficiency, focusing on its impact on epilepsy, anemia, and developmental delay.
results_summary: Uridine supplementation led to dramatic improvement in symptoms, including cessation of seizures, resolution of anemia, developmental progress, and prevention of severe manifestations when administered within 2 months of disease onset.
population_specificity: Two Chinese infants with CAD deficiency presenting with psychomotor developmental delay, drug-refractory epilepsy, and anemia.
study_duration: Intervention began within 2 months of disease onset; exact duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of a nucleotide (uridine, cytidine) and vitamin B12 combination versus a B vitamin combination for treating low back pain.
results_summary: The nucleotides+B12 group had fewer adverse events, no treatment discontinuations due to AEs, and superior pain reduction at 30 days compared to the B vitamin group, though both groups showed significant pain reduction and functional improvements by 60 days.
population_specificity: Adults with low back pain (n=634, split into two groups of 317 each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral activity of synthesized uridine glycoconjugates against two strains of TBEV (Hypr and Neudoerfl).
results_summary: Four compounds (18-21) showed strong antiviral activity against both TBEV strains, with IC50 values between 15.1 and 3.7 μM and high selectivity indices due to low cytotoxicity. These compounds may be promising candidates for further development against flaviviruses.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (IC50 values provided for compounds 18-21).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of CPBMF65, a UPP1 inhibitor, on activated hepatic stellate cells and carbon tetrachloride-induced liver fibrosis in mice.
results_summary: CPBMF65 reduced cell proliferation and promoted phenotype reversion in vitro, and demonstrated antifibrotic and anti-inflammatory effects in vivo, suggesting potential as a therapeutic agent for liver fibrosis.
population_specificity: Mice with carbon tetrachloride-induced liver fibrosis and activated hepatic stellate cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate an LC-MS/MS assay for quantifying uridine and DHO in human plasma to support clinical studies on pyrimidine synthesis biomarkers.
results_summary: The study successfully validated an LC-MS/MS method for uridine and DHO quantification in human plasma, demonstrating excellent accuracy, precision, and stability under various storage conditions. The assay was applied to human plasma samples to support clinical studies.
population_specificity: Human plasma samples (specific population not detailed beyond this).
effective_dosage: Not specified (assay validation study, not an intervention trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define the genotype and phenotype of CAD deficiency (EIEE-50) and evaluate the safety and efficacy of uridine supplementation as a treatment.
results_summary: Uridine supplementation (including uridine monophosphate and uridine triacetate) was safe and led to significant clinical improvement in most of the ten treated patients. The study confirmed CAD deficiency as a progressive disorder with epilepsy, developmental delays, and anemia, and identified milder cases with isolated intellectual disability or neonatal seizures.
population_specificity: 20 patients with CAD deficiency (EIEE-50), a rare genetic disorder affecting pyrimidine biosynthesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mutation characteristics and clinical relevance of Gilbert syndrome (GS) and Crigler-Najjar syndrome (CNS) in relation to the UGT1A1 gene.
